intro: Acaena cylindristachya var. macrophyllidion, commonly known as the large-leafed wood rose, is a flowering plant native to New Zealand. It belongs to the family Rosaceae and is characterized by its woody stems and showy, pinkish-red flowers. The plant produces small, berry-like fruits that are an important food source for native birds. It typically grows in moist, well-drained soils in forested areas. The leaves are broad and have a distinctive, serrated margin, contributing to its ornamental value.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acaena cylindristachya var. macrophyllidion is primarily native to New Zealand. It is found in the North Island and parts of the South Island. This variant is typically associated with coastal and lowland areas. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in open vegetation. The plant is part of the New Zealand flora and is adapted to the local climate and environmental conditions.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acaena cylindristachya var. macrophyllidion was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was brought there as part of the early European settlement and has since become naturalized in several regions. This plant is commonly found in coastal and lowland areas, often growing in disturbed soils. Its spread has been facilitated by its ability to thrive in a variety of environmental conditions. However, it is considered a potential weed in some areas due to its aggressive growth habit.
